articles.headline: Democrats See Perils on Path to Health Cuts
articles.snippet: Many Democrats fear that President Obama’s proposals will become a starting point for bigger cuts in popular health programs.
articles.abstract: Many Democrats fear that President Obama’s proposals will become a starting point for bigger cuts in popular health programs.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As Congress opens a politically charged exploration of ways to pare the deficit, President Obama is expected to seek hundreds of billions of dollars in savings in Medicare and Medicaid, delighting Republicans and dismaying many Democrats who fear that his proposals will become a starting point for bigger cuts in the popular health programs.

articles.headline: G.M. Looks to Shepherd U.A.W. Pact
articles.snippet: With the strongest balance sheet of Detroit’s Big Three, G.M. is in position to set the direction of the contract with autoworkers.
articles.abstract: With the strongest balance sheet of Detroit’s Big Three, G.M. is in position to set the direction of the contract with autoworkers.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — General Motors is aiming to set the framework of a new labor agreement with the United Automobile Workers union that would increase entry-level wages and establish a new profit-sharing formula for workers at all three Detroit car companies.
articles.byline: By Bill Vlasic and Nick Bunkley

articles.headline: Banks Brace for a Season of Fall-Offs
articles.snippet: In a bellwether for other large financial firms, JPMorgan Chase warned that third-quarter trading revenue was likely to fall about 8 percent from a year ago.
articles.abstract: In a bellwether for other large financial firms, JPMorgan Chase warned that third-quarter trading revenue was likely to fall about 8 percent from a year ago.
articles.lead_paragraph: The worries of Wall Street banks keep growing.

articles.headline: Tax Plan for Jobs Bill Has Familiar Ring
articles.snippet: Some proposals for taxes to pay for the jobs bill may sound familiar to Americans, like higher taxes on the rich and an end to some tax breaks like the one on corporate jets.
articles.abstract: Some proposals for taxes to pay for the jobs bill may sound familiar to Americans, like higher taxes on the rich and an end to some tax breaks like the one on corporate jets.
articles.lead_paragraph: To pay for his $447 billion jobs bill, President Obama is once again proposing an assortment of tax increases on wealthy individuals and corporations.

articles.headline: Demand at Target for Fashion Line Crashes Web Site
articles.snippet: In an unusual fumble, Target was unprepared for shoppers’ hunger for the limited-edition Missoni for Target line.
articles.abstract: In an unusual fumble, Target was unprepared for shoppers’ hunger for the limited-edition Missoni for Target line.
articles.lead_paragraph: Target’s Web site came crashing down on Tuesday as Missoni-loving fashion devotées invaded, scrambling to buy the high-end Italian designer’s clothes for a song.

articles.headline: U.S. Scrambles to Avert Palestinian Vote at U.N.
articles.snippet: The Obama administration is still seeking a compromise that would avoid a confrontation over Palestinian statehood at the United Nations next week.
articles.abstract: The Obama administration is still seeking a compromise that would avoid a confrontation over Palestinian statehood at the United Nations next week.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The United States is facing increasing pressure as the Palestinian quest for statehood gained support from Turkey and other countries, even as the Obama administration sought an 11th-hour compromise that would avoid a confrontation at the United Nations next week.
articles.byline: By Steven Lee Myers and David D. Kirkpatrick

articles.headline: Abuse of Xanax Leads a Clinic to Halt Supply
articles.snippet: Citing concern over overdoses, doctors at Seven Counties Services in Louisville have stopped writing prescriptions for the anti-anxiety drug Xanax.
articles.abstract: Citing concern over overdoses, doctors at Seven Counties Services in Louisville have stopped writing prescriptions for the anti-anxiety drug Xanax.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — Gayle Mink, a nurse practitioner at a community mental health center here, had tired of the constant stream of patients seeking Xanax, an anti-anxiety drug coveted for its swift calming effect.

articles.headline: In Rebuke to Iran’s President, Courts Void Release of Hikers
articles.snippet: President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad of Iran said with great fanfare this week that two American hikers would be freed. Not 24 hours later, Iran’s courts said he didn’t have the authority to free them.
articles.abstract: President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad of Iran said with great fanfare this week that two American hikers would be freed. Not 24 hours later, Iran’s courts said he didn’t have the authority to free them.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO — To pave the way for his annual visit to the United Nations, Iran’s president, Mahmoud Ahmadinejad, announced with great fanfare this week the imminent release of two American hikers sentenced to eight years for espionage.

articles.headline: Austere Italy? Check the Traffic
articles.snippet: A jobs-for-votes system entrenched at all levels of Italian politics may hinder the country’s efforts to cut its deficit and reassure the markets.
articles.abstract: A jobs-for-votes system entrenched at all levels of Italian politics may hinder the country’s efforts to cut its deficit and reassure the markets.
articles.lead_paragraph: COMITINI, Italy — With only 960 residents and a handful of roads, this tiny hilltop village in the arid, sulfurous hills of southern Sicily does not appear to have major traffic problems. But that does not prevent it from having one full-time traffic officer — and eight auxiliaries.

articles.headline: Germany and France Back Greece on Austerity Effort
articles.snippet: The leaders of France and Germany said they would support Greece’s role as a central part of the euro zone.
articles.abstract: The leaders of France and Germany said they would support Greece’s role as a central part of the euro zone.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — The Greek prime minister vowed Wednesday to persevere with austere cuts in the struggling country’s budget, while the leaders of France and Germany promised to support Greece’s continued membership in the euro zone.
articles.byline: By Steven Erlanger and Nicholas Kulish
